items.title: Remove android-api level 16 test for Fennec on mozilla-central
items.body:
Currently we experience failures in tests because the Android API level 16 Nightly builds of Fennec for mozilla-central are no longer existent for download. This is due to the deprecation plan.

https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/mobile/nightly/

As such the tests have to be removed here:

https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/blob/master/tests/remote/test_fennec.py

items.title: Skip remote tests for Thunderbird tinderbox builds
items.body:
Tinderbox builds seem to no longer be produced for Thunderbird across all branches (comm-central, beta, esr52) and as such the expiry policy kicked in and deleted the files for `comm-central` recently. Only `beta` and `esr52` remain, and I'm fairly sure those are gone too soon.

https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/tinderbox-builds/

As it looks like those builds are only available now via the TaskCluster index like:

https://tools.taskcluster.net/index/comm.v2.comm-central.latest.thunderbird/linux64-opt

@wsmwk do you know whom I could ask?

items.title: CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md file missing
items.body:
As of January 1 2019, Mozilla requires that all GitHub projects include this [CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md](https://github.com/mozilla/repo-templates/blob/master/templates/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) file in the project root. The file has two parts:

1. Required Text - All text under the headings *Community Participation Guidelines and How to Report*, are required, and should not be altered.
2. Optional Text - The Project Specific Etiquette heading provides a space to speak more specifically about ways people can work effectively and inclusively together. Some examples of those can be found on the [Firefox Debugger](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) project, and [Common Voice](https://github.com/mozilla/voice-web/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md). (The optional part is commented out in the [raw template file](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mozilla/repo-templates/blob/master/templates/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md), and will not be visible until you modify and uncomment that part.)

If you have any questions about this file, or Code of Conduct policies and procedures, please reach out to Mozilla-GitHub-Standards+CoC@mozilla.com.

_(Message COC001)_

items.title: Add "remote" pytest marker for remote tests and only run those tests in CI
items.body:
With issue #468 fixed soon, we can now mark specific functions to be not run by default when testing locally, but only when checks run in CI. This specifically applies to all the remote tests in https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/tree/master/tests/remote. 

A [pytest marker](https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/example/markers.html) should be added for each of those tests, and registered in the pytest.ini file.

By default those tests should not be run, but only when being executed in CI (Travis CI, AppVeyor). To get this done their appropriate configuration (yaml) files need to be updated.

items.title: Enhancement - download Firefox Developer Edition based on version
items.body:
Currently there is no way to generate an URL for Firefox Developer Edition based on version. This feature could be very helpful in our project.

Example of URL: http://archive.mozilla.org/pub/devedition/candidates/54.0b11-candidates/

Usage suggestion:
```
from mozdownload import FactoryScraper
scraper = FactoryScraper('devedition', version='41.0b9-candidates')
```

Since there are four files in the directory [https:github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/tree/master/tests/cli/](https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/tree/master/tests/cli/), it may be a good idea to submit one PR per file so that work can be done on small patches, one at a time.

items.title: Convert unit tests to plain pytest
items.body:
All of our tests for mozdownload still make use of the Python unittest framework, which is not necessary because pytest is used to execute all the tests. As such we should get rid of the test classes, and instead use fixtures. In https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/pull/467/commits/e0c9484b3a875cde305c59bd7ed5789c5410d179 I already converted `remote/test_firefox.py`.

We should do the same for all the remaining tests in the following sub folders: 

- [x] base_scraper
- [x] cli
- [x] daily_scraper
- [x] direct_scraper
- [x] directory_parser
- [x] factory
- [x] release_candidate_scraper
- [x] release_scraper
- [x] remote
- [x] tinderbox_scraper
- [x] treeherder
- [x] try_scraper

If you want to work on the fennec or thunderbird test please let us know here, and push a PR for only one of both at a time. That way we can divide the work. Thanks.

Once all of the above are done we can safely remove the `MozHttpdBaseTest` class in https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/blob/master/tests/mozhttpd_base_test.py.

items.title: FirefoxRemoteTests.test_tinderbox_scraper fails due to ReadTimeout exception
items.body:
Currently our tests are failing in `FirefoxRemoteTests.test_tinderbox_scraper` due to:

> ReadTimeout: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='archive.mozilla.org', port=443): Read timed out. (read timeout=60.0)

As it looks like the list of tinderbox builds is too long, and retrieving all the data exceeds the 60s timeout.

We should get this fixed to unblock us from landing new PRs.

beta/release: "Firefox Setup Stub 55.0b11.exe" => "Firefox Installer.exe"

items.title: Update package version dependencies
items.body: Before we do a new release of mozdownload we should bump the different dependent package versions.

items.title: Fix binary_regex for candidate/release scraper
items.body:
As noticed in https://github.com/mozilla/mozmill-ci/issues/828 we have a kinda strict limitation to our regex for the binary of candidate and release builds:

https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/blob/master/mozdownload/scraper.py#L601

The problem here is that we are not able to download some of the files when using `--extension` because there is a different file naming convention for Windows and MacOS:

https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/firefox/candidates/52.0b2-candidates/build1/win32/en-US/
https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/firefox/candidates/52.0b2-candidates/build1/mac/en-US/

This needs to be fixed. For the moment this will be ignored in setup.cfg, but we should really fix this.

items.title: Add support for pyup.io

items.title: Failure in test_optional_authentication: [Errno -2] Name or service not known
pylama failures
items.body:
In PR #412, we are seeing a bunch of pylama failures in appveyor and travis.

Before we can land the above PR we need to resolve those issues.

Minimal suggestionon what to do are to add at least a config file for pylama including an allowed line-length of 100 chars instead of 80 only.

items.title: Explanation of tox usage in README
items.body:
I was absent during the change to tox as a testing environment and was not aware of the package.

As a consequence, I had no idea how to start running the tests.

This should be outlined somewhere, most likely in the README...

items.title: Allow to run individual test files / folders via tox
items.body:
I would like to run a single folder with tests or a test only via tox. Therefore {posargs} can be used.

@Motwani do you want to do the small change?

items.title: Add coverage support for py.test run
items.body: We would like to know our test coverage for code under the mozdownload directory. Therefore we need the coverage tool installed and used. As a start we could have a look at mozregression in how it's doing it: https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression.

items.title: Add pylama call to tox config file
items.body:
Right now we are running pylama only for Travis and AppVeyor. It would be good to add this call to the tox.ini file instead so that we can also benefit from that in local testing.

@Motwani would you like to take this issue?

$ mozdownload -t tinderbox
INFO | Downloading from: https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/firefox/tinderbox-builds/mozilla-central-linux64/1456743888/firefox-47.0a1.en-US.linux-x86_64.sdk.tar.bz2

items.title: Release version 1.20.2
items.body:
If it happens once it can happen a second time! So we need another bug fix release given that querying Treeherder is broken with the platform filter applied. The fix will land soon, so we can release a new version today.

The following tasks have to be performed:
- [x] Land all blockers
- [x] Update setup.py for version bump
- [x] Update changelog
- [x] Tag version 1.20.2
- [x] Release to pypi (sdist and bdist_wheel packages)

items.title: Querying Treeherder by revision fails due to invalid usage of platform value
items.body:
The unittests haven't caught this problem but a late refactoring on PR #370 broke the filter for the API request of jobs:

"GET /api/project/mozilla-beta/jobs/?platform=build_platform&result_set_id=2441562&job_type_name=Build&option_collection_hash=102210fe594ee9b33d82058545b1ed14f4c8206e&exclusion_profile=False HTTP/1.1" 200 None

Notice the invalid value of `build_platform` as actual platform value.

items.title: Release version 1.20.1
items.body:
Mozdownload 1.20 was a busted release so we have to release a minor update with the fix included. To ensure that we don't fail again I also added coverage for OS X and Windows. So I feel way better now.

The following tasks have to be performed:
- [x] Land all blockers
- [x] Update setup.py for version bump
- [x] Update History.md (git changelog --list)
- [x] Tag version 1.20.1 
- [x] Release to pypi (sdist, bdist-wheel)

items.title: Make use of Travis' container based infrastructure
items.body:
To speed-up test execution we should make use of the container based infrastructure. This require only a small change.

Details:
http://docs.travis-ci.com/user/migrating-from-legacy/

items.title: Add Appveyor support for running unittests on Windows
items.body: We should use http://www.appveyor.com/ to run our unittest on Windows. An example you can find in the mozregression repository: https://github.com/mozilla/mozregression/blob/master/appveyor.yml

items.title: Also release wheel packages for mozdownload
items.body: @edmorley mentioned to me that he would like to have a wheel package of mozdownload. I would have to update my release process according to the information as given on [bug 1220108](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1220108#c1).

items.title: mozdownload command fails with: "error: unrecognized arguments: mozdownload"
items.body:
The following change seems to have busted the CLI command of mozdownload:
https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/pull/370/files#diff-2204333307f1f8807918caa9eec87871R144

The one cli test we have only checks for the output of the global doc string, which we now always show in the help. That said we have no test coverage for this specific case and so the issue was not recognized. :(

Looks like we need a bustage release.

items.title: Add Travis support for OS X
items.body:
Right now we only run our unit tests on Linux hosts via Travis. We should expand the testing to OS X.

https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/osx-ci-environment/

items.title: Fix unit tests for Windows
items.body:
Two of our unittests are currently failing on Windows because of a missing platform specifier:
- https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/blob/master/tests/cli/test_correct_scraper.py#L17
- https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/blob/master/tests/factory/test_factory_scraper.py#L13

We should ensure to always specify a platform or use mock to test different platforms.

items.title: Release version 1.20
items.body:
We haven't had a release of mozdownload for a long time. Lots of new cool features have been added and bugs fixed. So lets get a new release out.

The following tasks have to be performed:
- [x] Land all blockers
- [x] Update setup.py for version bump
- [x] Update changelog
- [x] Tag version 1.20
- [x] Release to pypi

items.title: Bump dependencies to mozinfo 0.9 and requests 2.9.1
items.body: At least for mozinfo and for requests we can bump the version up to the latest version before we release version 1.20 of mozdownload.

items.title: Use wptserve for unit tests
items.body: Right now the unittests make use of mozhttpd. The development of this HTTP server has been stopped in favor of [wptserve](https://github.com/w3c/wptserve).

items.title: Fix PEP warnings in source files under mozdownload/
items.body: With the latest version of pylama including pep8 I see a huge amount of warnings in my editor for all the source files. This bugs me a lot given that it makes it hard to spot real warnings. So I'm going to get them fixed.

items.title: Fennec API level 11 got replaced with API level 15
items.body: Since January 29th there are no API level 11 builds produced anymore on mozilla-central. As result the remote Fennec tests are failing. We should get the new API level 15 added and limit API level 11 testing until Jan 28th.

items.title: Improve logging and arguments handling
items.body:
We made a couple of changes in the last months but never really refactored the details about argument handling and logging. Especially the latter is a bit broken (actually since we make use of it) and is blocking me in implementing a good logging strategy on issue #354.

I have local changes working which will improve the situation a lot. I will upload it soon.

items.title: Use pytest as testrunner for unit tests
Let `latest` for release and candidate point to latest version
items.body: With the move to S3 we no longer have symlinks under the latest sub directories. I think we should keep allowing `latest` as version, and have to scrape on our own for the latest version.

items.title: Get daily, tinderbox, and try builds by revision
items.body:
A requested feature for a long time. Finally with the help of Treeherder we can get this implemented. It's not that easy but with a couple of API requests it can be done. So here an example for one of the latest beta-releases which happened to be:

https://treeherder.mozilla.org/#/jobs?repo=mozilla-beta&revision=5c042dab34a2

Steps to do:
- Get the resultset for the given revision: https://treeherder.mozilla.org/api/project/mozilla-beta/resultset/?revision=5c042dab34a257de85b7eaf2bc81aaad16b8a1b0
- Retrieve the option collection hash to use: https://treeherder.mozilla.org/api/optioncollectionhash/
- With the `results[0]['id']` (2441562) found you can query for all the jobs run for this particular changeset. What we want is to apply filters to reduce the time until we got all results. Keep in mind that we need a hash for Treeherder supported platforms and similar: https://treeherder.mozilla.org/api/project/mozilla-beta/jobs/?result_set_id=2441562&count=2000&exclusion_profile=false&job_type_name=Build&platform=linux32&option_collection_hash=102210fe594ee9b33d82058545b1ed14f4c8206e 
- With the `results[0]['id']` (737977) found you can query for the artifacts of the job: https://treeherder.mozilla.org/api/project/mozilla-beta/artifact/?job_id=737977&name=Job+Info&type=json
- We can use the log URL strip of the filename and take that as base path for all the files contained in this folder.

items.title: Make use of tox as test runner for unit tests
items.body:
We should make use of [tox](https://testrun.org/tox/latest/) as testrunner for our unit tests. It has some nice features like automatic environment creation which would help us a lot here. Maybe we could even integrate coverage reports at the same time.

For an example see the mozharness tox configuration file:
http://mxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/testing/mozharness/tox.ini

items.title: TestCLICorrectScraper and TestFactoryCorrectScraper fail on OS X
items.body: The best I can tell they have tests for the correct default platform being chosen and we assume that is linux, this assumption is incorrect on OS X.

items.title: test_optional_authentication is broken
items.body:
`test_optional_authentication` [1] attempts to use https://ci.mozilla.org, that site is down and they're planning on decommissioning it [2].

This has the unfortunate side effect of making PRs seem like they've caused test failures.

[1] https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/blob/master/tests/base_scraper/test_base_scraper.py#L99
[2] https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1229734

items.title: scraper.url should return a properly html encoded URL
items.body:
Using the mozdownload scraper API to get the URL of the target build can result in broken output due to a missing html encoding. That's why the `url` property should automatically encode the URL.

You can test it with: `mozdownload -p mac -t candidate -v 43.0b8`

Current result:

> http://archive.mozilla.org/pub/firefox/candidates/43.0b8-candidates/build1/mac/en-US/Firefox 43.0b8.dmg

items.title: Add option to print final url to standard output
items.body: It would be helpful to have an option to let mozdownload print the final url to stdout. It could be used with pipes to pass into another application or stored to disk.

items.title: Make progressbar dependency optional
items.body: Not everyone may need the neat output of the progressbar while downloading a build. So we might want to make it optional in setup.py. As replacement we could offer a minimal status line similar to what mozregression does.

items.title: Move BASE_URL from https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org to https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/
items.body:
Follow-up from https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/commit/ea76769ef8cb62091ea85bf76d79df8098b0e635#commitcomment-13965099.

Not sure why I reverted to the formerly archive.m.o base URL and haven't used that one here. I hope that the currently used sub folder will still be in place for a while, so no emergency release of mozdownload is necessary again. I asked @nthomas-mozilla on IRC about that. So lets wait for his feedback.

items.title: How to download Firefox 40.0 32-bit Win32?
items.body:
I'm trying to verify if Firefox 40.0 had a bug that could have been fixed in Firefox 41.0, so I'm attempting to get FF 40.0 Win32 as a zip package, with the following:

```
mozdownload --type=release --version=40.0 --platform=win32 --extension=zip
```

or

```
mozdownload --type=release --version=40.0 --platform=win32
```

but both of those give

```
mozdownload.errors.NotFoundError: Specified build has not been found: https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/firefox/releases/40.0/win32/en-US
```

Unfortunately from the error message, I'm at a dead end to what I'm doing wrong. As a workaround, I'm uninstalling Firefox, and installing manually from installer, but it would be nice to be able to download a .zip file of a release via mozdownload and unzip it to a temp directory for quick testing. If this is possible, perhaps it might be something to add to the example command line invocations?

items.title: mozdownload is no longer able to download builds from archive.mozilla.org
items.body:
Via [bug 1211732](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1211732) the files on archive.mozilla.org have been moved to S3. That means the HTML is different now and mozdownload fails to download any build.

As a quick workaround we can change the BASE_URL to `http://ftp-origin-scl3.mozilla.org/` to keep mozdownload working. 

I will get this fixed in a bit.

@xabolcs maybe that is what you were seeing?

items.title: Use a shared HTTP/HTTPS session() for retrieving data
items.body: As of now we seem to make individual connections to the remote host for querying every tiny information and finally downloading the build. It would be better to share those connections via a session (http://docs.python-requests.org/en/latest/user/advanced/#session-objects). It can result in a more or less good speed improvement.

items.title: Ensure to have good API properties and methods
items.body:
Given that the upcoming version 1.18 of mozdownload will have a good API for using it, we should make sure that the properties and methods we provide can easily be used and are named appropriately.

Right now we have `final_url` for the remote location which would have to be renamed to just `url`. Otherwise it might become confusing. Also the local filename can be retrieved via `target`. It's better to rename this property to `filename` instead.

Maybe there are others but lets see.

items.title: Create Factory class for various Scraper instances
items.body: Right now it is kinda hard to create the correct scraper. We should make it easier to create a specific one by just having a factory class which accepts various arguments and automatically creates the wanted scraper instance for you.

items.title: Switch from optparse to argparse
items.body: We should finally switch from the old optparse module to argparse. I will have a PR up in a bit. For now it will depend on issue #316.

items.title: Move CLI into its own module
items.body: Having the CLI code in the scraper doesn't make sense and only blows up its size. Lets separate it out into its own module.

items.title: Add CONTRIBUTING.md file for instructions
items.body:
According to [this guideline](https://github.com/blog/1184-contributing-guidelines) we should have a CONTRIBUTING.md file in our repository, which will help contributors to get started, and reviewers/owners how to handle the repository. Right now all that information is located in the [wiki](https://github.com/mozilla/mozdownload/wiki#contributing) which might be missed.

Thanks to @AutomatedTester for the hint. I will work on that.

items.title: Enhance documentation for developer related activities
items.body:
Hey, I was setting up mozdownload on Windows, and when learning for the first time, I was scratching my head on the following for a moment:
1. I did not know what to do with the git repo after cloning. There was no mozdownload script included, and readme did not have Windows instructions. Running "python setup.py" gave this:
   
   ```
   C:\code\mozdownload>python setup.py
   usage: setup.py [global_opts] cmd1 [cmd1_opts] [cmd2 [cmd2_opts] ...]
      or: setup.py --help [cmd1 cmd2 ...]
      or: setup.py --help-commands
      or: setup.py cmd --help
   
   error: no commands supplied
   ```

and I did not know how to proceed.
1. On the web page https://pypi.python.org/pypi/mozdownload , the first two links are broken, so I wondered if the package had gone stale altogether over time and not used anymore.
2. Then I just randomly tried "pip install mozdownload", following the instructions that exist for installing the mozregression tool for Windows here: http://mozilla.github.io/mozregression/install.html and that worked! It would be good to document similar "Installing on Windows"
3. Running the first example command on Windows gives the following error:
   
   ```
   C:\code\mozdownload>mozdownload --version=latest
   Traceback (most recent call last):
     File "C:\Python27\Scripts\mozdownload-script.py", line 9, in <module>
       load_entry_point('mozdownload==1.17', 'console_scripts', 'mozdownload')()
     File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\mozdownload\scraper.py", line 1244, in cli
       build.download()
     File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\mozdownload\scraper.py", line 275, in download
       if os.path.isfile(os.path.abspath(self.target)):
     File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\mozdownload\scraper.py", line 237, in target
       self.build_filename(self.binary))
     File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\mozdownload\scraper.py", line 190, in binary
       raise errors.NotFoundError(message, self.path)
   mozdownload.errors.NotFoundError: Specified build has not been found: https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/firefox/releases/latest/win64/en-US
   ```

which I could not understand. Whimboo explained on IRC that it's because it attempts to find 64-bit release builds for Windows, which do not exist.

Downloading the mozilla-central builds is what I was after, and eventually I was able to get it working. Thanks for the great tool! Just wanted to point out these observations to ease the Windows first run experience.

items.title: Remove dependency for mozlog
items.body: Currently we are using mozlog to print logging statements.  But with PR #300 we only use this module once for getting the actual logger. I feel it's time to kill the dependency and simply setup our logger via the logging module.

items.title: AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'getLogger'
items.body:
This error occurs on the latest (master) version of mozdownload::

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/user/.local/bin/mozdownload", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('mozdownload==1.16', 'console_scripts', 'mozdownload')()
  File "/home/user/.local/venvs/mozdownload/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mozdownload/scraper.py", line 1248, in cli
    build = BUILD_TYPES[options.type](**kwargs)
  File "/home/user/.local/venvs/mozdownload/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mozdownload/scraper.py", line 592, in __init__
    Scraper.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/user/.local/venvs/mozdownload/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mozdownload/scraper.py", line 107, in __init__
    self.logger = mozlog.getLogger(' ')
```

It looks like the latest version of mozlog no longer supports the API mozdownload is trying to use.

items.title: We can't determine the latest beta and release candidate
items.body:
https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/firefox/candidates/latest-beta-candidates does not exist anymore. Creating the symlink is probably not automated anymore as part of the release process. [1]

There are various options we have in here:
- parse the candidates page and find the most recent _beta_ folder "37.0b7-candidates"
- mozci allows you to navigate through all of the scheduling data from the releng systems
  *\* I just inspected the buildjson file of 2015-03-20 and contains all the data we would need [2]
- We can also determine the latest version from the releng configs [3]

I suggest we go for option 2 since mozci will become a long term project that allows us to inspect data about any jobs on the Releng CI.

[1]
armenzg@armenzg-thinkpad:~/repos/mozdownload$ mozdownload -t candidate -v latest-beta
https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/firefox
HEY HEY
  INFO | Retrieving list of candidate builds from https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/firefox/candidates/latest-beta-candidates/
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/mozdownload", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('mozdownload==1.14', 'console_scripts', 'mozdownload')()
  File "/home/armenzg/repos/mozdownload/mozdownload/scraper.py", line 1255, in cli
    build = BUILD_TYPES[options.type](**kwargs)
  File "/home/armenzg/repos/mozdownload/mozdownload/scraper.py", line 642, in **init**
    Scraper.**init**(self, _args, *_kwargs)
  File "/home/armenzg/repos/mozdownload/mozdownload/scraper.py", line 160, in **init**
    raise NotFoundError(message, e.response.url)
mozdownload.scraper.NotFoundError: Specified build has not been found: https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/firefox/candidates/latest-beta-candidates/

[2] http://builddata.pub.build.mozilla.org/builddata/buildjson/builds-2015-03-20.js.gz
        "packageUrl": "http://stage.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/firefox/nightly/37.0b7-candidates/build1/win32/en-US/firefox-37.0b7.zip",
